SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: The utility of cardiac stress testing as a risk-stratification tool before kidney transplantation remains debatable owing to discordance with coronary angiography and outcome yields at different centers
METHODS: We conducted a retrospective study of 273 diabetic kidney transplant recipients from 2006 to 2010
By protocol, all diabetic patients underwent pharmacological radionucleotide stress test or dobutamine stress echocardiography before transplant
We compared the 1-year cardiac outcomes between those with negative stress test results and those with positive stress test results
RESULTS: Patients with a positive stress test result (n=67) underwent coronary angiogram, and significant coronary artery disease (â‰¥70% coronary stenosis) was found in 35 (52.2%) patients
Of the latter, 32 (91.4%) underwent cardiac revascularization (24 underwent cardiac stenting and 8 underwent coronary artery bypass grafting)

Within 1 year after transplant, the group with positive stress test results experienced more cardiac events (34.3% vs. 3.9%, P<0.001) including acute myocardial infarction (22.4% vs. 3.4%, P<0.001) and ventricular arrhythmias (8.9% vs. 0.05%, P=0.001), higher all-cause mortality (19.4% vs. 4.8%, P<0.001), and cardiac mortality (17.9% vs. 0.9%, P<0.001) compared with the group with negative stress test results
CONCLUSIONS: In this diabetic population, stress testing showed positive and negative predictive values of 34.3% and 96.1%, respectively
Pharmacological cardiac stress testing provided excellent risk stratification in diabetic kidney transplant recipients
